Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: An open class is scheduled at the school, and the mother should attend
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: I woke up early, already feeling the weight of the day pressing on my chest. Today was Aarav’s open class at school, and he had been talking about it for weeks, his eyes shining with excitement every time he mentioned showing me his art project. As a mother, I knew how important it was to be there, to sit in the front row and cheer him on. But as I prepared breakfast, my mind kept drifting to the small altar in the corner of our living room. My daily puja was more than a habit—it was a promise to myself and my faith, a way to keep my heart anchored. Lately, I had been rushing through it, sometimes only whispering a mantra under my breath as I hurried out the door. Today, with the open class scheduled right after my usual prayer time, I felt the familiar tug-of-war inside me. If I stayed for the full ritual, I might be late for Aarav. If I left early, I would break the rhythm of my devotion. The expectations from both sides pressed in, and I stood in the kitchen, torn, the clock ticking louder with every passing second.
